docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Sept. 11 Ringleader Linked to Qaeda Camps Germany has gathered evidence that Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 attacks, and two accomplices trained at Qaeda camps in Afghanistan from late 1999 to early 2000. Investigators have also established a clear link between Al Qaeda and a recent attack on a Tunisian synagogue. A1 Deadly Russian Politics Russian assassins have trained guns, bombs and even vials of acid on a bewildering array of political officeholders. The deaths are a testament to both the frailty of Russia's emerging justice system and the depth of official corruption. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: With the American president a conspicuous exception, leaders from nearly 100 nations will begin assembling next week in Johannesburg to address the future of life on this planet. At the heart of the conference is a formidable if now familiar challenge -- figuring out ways to bring economic well-being to billions of people now trapped in poverty without destroying the land, water, air and biodiversity required to sustain life itself. It will be the third such meeting in three decades, and if the past is any guide, the Johannesburg conclave -- known formally as the World Summit on Sustainable Development -- will be long on good intentions and short on specific solutions. Even so, it is a meeting well worth having. The Stockholm summit in 1972 inspired the industrialized nations to begin cleaning up their air and water. The Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in 1992 produced treaties on global warming and biodiversity that, while vague, officially committed at least the industrialized nations to address two major environmental threats that had long gone unattended. In the last decade these challenges have not receded, while others have arisen.
docs.abstract: Editorial says World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg will be long on good intentions and short on specific solutions, judging by earlier conclaves; says Pres Bush's absence is regrettable and reinforces his well-deserved reputation for indifference to environmental problems and reflexive hostility to multilateral remedies

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal jury convicted the town president of Cicero and six other people today of stealing $12 million from the town, which for decades has been clouded by accusations of mob influence. Also convicted was Michael Spano Sr., who prosecutors have said is the boss of organized crime in Cicero, a city of 85,000 people that abuts western Chicago.

headline.main: Town President Is Convicted In Scheme to Steal $12 Million

docs.abstract: Betty Loren-Maltese, town president of Cicero, Ill, and six other people are convicted of stealing $12 million from town's employee insurance program; prosecutors say much of money was used to buy hotel with golf course in Wisconsin, Indiana horse farm, vacation house and luxury cars; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The union representing teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools in New York City and its suburbs announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract that calls for an 11 percent raise and improved retirement benefits. The union, the Lay Faculty Association, reached the accord with the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York after a five-week strike last winter and months of tense, occasionally nasty, negotiations. Three months ago, a state labor board found the archdiocese guilty of bargaining in bad faith, and an annual dinner expected to raise $500,000 for the archdiocese was canceled when the teachers threatened to picket outside.

headline.main: Teachers and Catholic Archdiocese Reach a Tentative Contract

docs.lead_paragraph: It had to happen eventually. Chinatown already spills over into two neighborhoods moving from modest to mod: Little Italy and the Lower East Side. And it is just a cellphone's throw from TriBeCa and SoHo. Gentrification was bound to come to Chinatown. Now that it has arrived, the neighborhood is experiencing the usual side effects, including landlords trying to evict longtime tenants who pay very little rent in favor of deep-pocketed bond traders.

headline.main: Chinatown Gentrifies, and Evicts; Complaints of Safety Violations Now Coming From Landlords

docs.abstract: As gentrification spreads to Chinatown, landlords who want to evict tenants living in illegal subdivisions and paying very low rents in favor of those willing to pay market rates are armed with city's building codes; many immigrants can afford little more than squalid rooms in illegally subdivided apartments and are being evicted; highlights need for more low-income housing; photos (M)

byline.original: By CLAYTON DEKORNE and JAVAID KHAN

docs.lead_paragraph: This was the year that a huge class of newcomers would bring a fresh sense of activism and urgency to the City Council, furiously passing laws and creating a true partnership with the mayor. Things have not quite worked out that way. Despite its high spirits and a constant flood of proposals, this City Council is on track to be the least prolific in more than a decade. Caught up in assembling its own bureaucracy from scratch and wringing budget restorations out of the Bloomberg administration, the Council has moved much more slowly than its predecessors in putting new laws on the books.

headline.main: City Hall Memo; Council Full Of Neophytes Gets Off To Slow Start

docs.abstract: New York City City Council, who is made up of many newcomers, is on track to be least prolific in more than decade; Council has moved much more slowly than its predecessors in putting new laws on books (M)
